urn:contentItem:5Y5T-4JB1-F0J6-J54D-00000-00Are the bushfires a pivotal moment? 'If not, we're stuffed', says former fire chief2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Are the bushfires a pivotal moment? 'If not, we're stuffed', says former fire chiefJolyon Attwooll

Two former fire chiefs have spoken to The Courier about their growing frustration with the national approach to tackling bushfires.

Both Neil Bibby, Victoria's former CFA boss, and Ewan Waller, the former chief fire officer of Forest Fire Management Victoria, expressed their hope that the recent devastation would lead to a profound shift in the national approach.

Both were among the 23 signatories - all former emergency services leaders - of a letter to Prime Minister Scott Morrison last autumn, calling for more action to address "catastrophic extreme weather conditions" and climate change.

In November, Mr Bibby warned of the "clear and present danger" facing the Ballarat region and huge swathes of the rest of the country. He says his frustration has grown as he has watched one of the most devastating fire seasons on record unfold - with months still to go.

"This goes back to March when we first raised the issue. Now we are playing catch-up," he said. "I keep telling people that the fires are just a symptom of a disease called climate change. Federal government has to take leadership here."

His words were echoed by Mr Waller, who said: "What I am looking for is national leadership, and to be bold and far-sighted... looking 20, 30 years out to how we are going to adapt and adjust to this new climate regime.

"I'm not seeing any signs of that and that's disappointing. It's testing the quality of our leadership.

"If you look at some of the good governments, like Hawke's and Howard's ...they worked within the electoral cycle but they also were statesmanlike and looked far and did some profound things.

"That's what I am looking for out of this - our leaders stand up and say it is a real challenge and rally us. The time is ripe for that. It will take some guts to do it."

TECHNOLOGY AND PREVENTION While both emphasise leadership, their focus is on separate aspects of fire-fighting and prevention.

Mr Bibby stresses how innovation should be part of the key to tackling blazes. He gives the example of helicopters with infrared equipment to pinpoint hotspots after lightning strikes.

"We need helicopters up there immediately, not two days later," he said. "The days of waiting for a fire to come to you have gone, you have got to be in there and first attack and nip those fires in the bud."

He also welcomed the investment in the National Aerial Firefighting Centre. "They do a heck of a lot with the dollars they are given," he said. "They've just been given an injection of additional dollars for this year - that needs to be ongoing."

Mr Waller, meanwhile, raises the topic of fuel and land management, a subject he acknowledges is "politically fraught" - much to his personal frustration.

"Good bush management is the only tool we've got really on the broad area," he said.

"If we're saying [as] was said recently by senior fire people and the government that it's not going to be picked up, we're virtually walking away from the bush and saying 'the bush is going to get cooked regularly every five to 10 years' and we're going to put up with that'. That's completely unacceptable.

"To say it's too difficult, to me it's un-Australian. It's got to be resourced [and] well planned. It's got to happen."

For him, the issue is very pertinent to Ballarat. "I worry about the outskirts around Ballarat, places like Creswick, they are quite vulnerable, particularly the small hobby farms," he said.

"Fire can get in there and move quickly and do a lot of damage. We've got too much of the season to go. We've got three months of difficult times [ahead]."

READ THE LETTER FROM EMERGENCY LEADERS (FROM LAST AUTUMN)

RESOURCES Both, unsurprisingly, emphasise the need for more 'boots on the ground'. Mr Bibby feels the burden on the CFA volunteers is becoming too heavy.

"What the nation has to come to grips with is that it can't ride on the back of volunteers for the next... decades.

"We have to look at how we manage and support volunteers so they can properly assist us but they can also have a life in their own right and earn some money at the jobs they're paid for," he said.

He pointed to the many Victorian volunteers who had gone to Queensland earlier in the season. "You can't run an organisation on volunteers that are already exhausted from what they have been doing in other states before they get to their own state."

Even spreading resources within the state was likely to become problematic, he suggested, pointing at the many Ballarat-based volunteers involved in the fire-fighting in East Gippsland.

"Some hard decisions have to be made about keeping people at home in case something occurs," he said.

Mr Waller also raised the pressure on resources. "Land management, the resourcing of the bush, it's been cut and cut and cut... Now we've got offices with nobody in them.

He gave the example of Corryong being under-staffed and called for more "middle managers and scientists" in the field.

"They need more people living in those communities, understanding what is happening in those communities, understanding the bush," he said.

A DEFINING MOMENT? Both hope the damage done - economically, environmentally and on a human level - will inspire a more coordinated approach.

Mr Bibby wants a national workshop after the fire season is over to consider how we are going to manage the fire danger in the future.

He also advocates a national climate change framework akin to that in place at a state level in Victoria.

"It acknowledges that it is a problem, as opposed to [putting] your head in the sand and [saying] it's not a problem," he said.

"This is a climate change event. When I first started in the fire industry 46 years ago, major fires like the ones we are confronting now were every 10 years, then they moved to every six years, then every three years and now it's almost every year."

Mr Waller meanwhile describes this season's fires as a "third fundamental disturbance" into how we treat the bush. First he cites the dismissal of First Nations' management of the bush by early European arrivals; the second was the introduction of agriculture; now the fires of the 2019/20 season.

"It has to reshape how we manage the bush. It's questioning a lot of how we approach protection and conservation values," he said.

He is also candid about his reservations on whether a bipartisan approach is likely at federal level.

"I am doubtful, it's not the style of government, particularly not the style of this government, [to have] a joint approach to things," said Mr Waller.

Whether it leads to a co-ordinated approach or not, both former fire chiefs hope the unprecedented blazes could be a pivotal moment in the nation's history. "I hope it is. I think it will be," Mr Waller said.

Mr Bibby's response to the question is pithier still: "If it isn't, we're stuffed."

urn:contentItem:5Y1K-BG91-F0JP-W4S4-00000-00THE FACES OF HEARTBREAK2020-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10THE FACES OF HEARTBREAK

An unrelenting summer of fires has claimed the lives of 29 much- loved Australians, leaving a trail of heartache across the country.

Vivian Chaplain, 69 Diehard, NSW AS THE Kangawalla blaze tore through the tranquil NSW Northern Tablelands community of Wytaliba, Vivian Chaplain (below) called her daughter-in-law Chrystal Harwood in a panic.

The 69-year-old, who had stayed behind to protect her home and animals, asked for her son and his father to help her fight the flames, but they couldn't get through.

Ms Chaplain was found unconscious near her shed, suffering burns to at least 40 per cent of her body and later died at Concord Hospital on November 8. She had moved to the area to live a peaceful, sustainable life on her own little piece of land, Ms Harwood said.

"She was amazingly strong and very stubborn," she said.

"We all knew she would have stood there with a hose trying to fight it and trying to save the animals."

George Nole, 85 Diehard, NSW GEORGE Nole (below) was found dead in a burnt-out car at the Kangawalla fire zone. The Greek-born Australian was an electronics genius who had worked on NASA's Apollo missions, but moved to the isolated village of Wytaliba to "be himself", friends said.

The Wytaliba community Mr Nole joined in the 1980s was a laid-back place popular with nudists. He was a stalwart of the community, often riding his cycle around the village, and voted for the Sex Party.

"The 86-year-old had a sticker on his car which read 'Sexy Senior Citizen'," local Brett Miller said.

Mr Nole was known to attend parties in Lederhosen and was a "reclusive nudist". "There was a bell at the front of his house that you would ring to tell him you were coming," Mr Miller said.

"That would give him enough time to put some undies or something on. "If you didn't ring that and just went to the door, he would just open it and you would get the full view." Friends said Mr Nole had been diagnosed with leukaemia in 2014 and had been prepared to die.

Barry Parsons, 58 Willawarrin, NSW BARRY Parsons (below) left a haunting Facebook post as fire bore down on his Willawarrin property, north-west of Kempsey, where he lived alone in a shed.

"Seriously looks and sounds like apocalypse out there. F--ked up being on your own in these times," he wrote.

His body was found five days later, on November 8, in burnt-out bushland not far from his shed where locals, who described him as a "kind and caring person", said he would care for stray cats.

Geoffrey Keaton, 32, and Andrew O'Dwyer, 35 Buxton, NSW THE young volunteer firefighters, best mates and fathers, Geoffrey Keaton and Andrew O'Dwyer (above), died on December 19 in terrifying conditions battling the Green Wattle Creek fire near Buxton.

A burnt gum, the type sadly called widow-makers, crashed on to the cab of their fire truck, killing them instantly and injuring the three rural fire crew members in the back seat.

At their funerals, their young children Charlotte O'Dwyer, 18 months, and -Harvey Keaton, 19 months, were told their dads had left only because they were heroes. The pair were remembered as devoted dads who loved nothing better than swapping photographs and tales of their toddlers as they were both farewelled with full Rural Fire Service honours.

Mr O'Dwyer's wife Melissa said: "The boys have always got each other's back." Mr Keaton's fiancee Jess Hayes said Geoff was "a super proud dad who did anything to help his family and friends".

Julie Fletcher, 63 Johns River, NSW JULIE Fletcher's body was found in her burnt-out home on November 10, two days after she died before she could escape a fast-moving fire at Johns River, between Port Macquarie and Taree.

Her family had once owned most of the property around Johns River where they ran dairy cattle, and neighbours said animal-lover Ms Fletcher loved her angus cattle so much that she could never sell them for slaughter.

"Her cows died old and happy," her friend and neighbour Diny Khan, 63, said.

Samuel McPaul, 28 Jingellic, NSW FATHER-TO-BE and volunteer firefighter Sam McPaul died on December 30 when a freak fire tornado flipped his eight-tonne RFS truck at Jingellic, outside Albury on the southern NSW border.

He was with the Culcairn North West brigade as they fought to save properties along the Murray River and his crew had entered a paddock to round up cattle.

They were on flat ground, just 50m from the farm gate with little around them to burn. But the Green Valley fire was so large, it created its own weather system, known as a pyrocumulonimbus, whipping up 140km/h winds. Two of his crew mates were injured.

Mr McPaul and his wife Megan (both above) were married for 18 months and she was pregnant with their first child.

Culcairn fire captain Andrew Godde, who was in charge of the truck, described Mr McPaul as a "ripping young bloke" who always put others before himself.

"You hear people talk about these fireballs, but I've never experienced anything like that before," he said.

Robert Salway, 63, and son Patrick Salway, 29 Wandella, NSW WELL-KNOWN dairy farmers Robert Salway, 63, and his son Patrick described as "salt of the earth", died on December 30 while trying to save their home and farming equipment from the raging Badja Forest fire tornado, which went on to destroy the main street of historic NSW town Cobargo.

The pair (below) were found dead the following morning when Patrick's mother Janelle Salway returned to the family farm called Ashwood at Wandeall, about 10km north-west of Cobargo in the Bega Valley.

Patrick, whose best-known saying was "It'll be right" and his pregnant wife Renee, own a business called South Coast Diary Tech, where Patrick, a boilermaker and welder, looked after many local dairy farmers in the state's south.

Renee and the couple's little boy Harley left the property before the fires arrived.

She posted on social media shortly after their death and said that her family was "broken" as they dealt with the loss of the young father. "I love you now, I love you still, I always have and I always will. I will see you again Patrick, my best friend," she said.

In more tragedy for the family, within 30 hours of their death, Robert's elderly mother Edna died without ever learning of her son and grandson's fate.

Laurie Andrews, 70 Yatte Yattah, NSW LAURIE Andrews, 70, was found dead on December 31 outside his home on Myrtle Gully Rd, Yatte Yattah, after the deadly Currowan bushfire swept through the area and neighbouring Conjola.

Mr Andrews was a founding member of the Mollymook Longboarders and was remembered by his surfing mates as an "all round great bloke" and stylish surfer.

Police said his body had no trauma or significant burns, and they did not believe there were any suspicious circumstances involved.

Col Burns, 72 Belowra, NSW VOLUNTEER firefighter Col Burns, 72, (below) wasn't on duty, but he died protecting his own isolated property in the Belowra Valley from the out-of-control 64,000ha Badja Forest Rd fire on December 31.

It was the same fire that flared in the east, hitting hard NSW towns, including Cobargo.

The isolated tiny hamlet of Belowra, with just nine residents, was ringed by fire and locals reported that Mr Burns was unaccounted for.

But it was several days before emergency services could get to Mr Burns and his body was found.

David Harrison, 47 Batlow, NSW DAVID Harrison (below) died on January 4 of a heart attack as he battled to save his best mate's home from the Dunns Rd blaze that swept through the apple town.

He had known Geoff Purcell since school and refused to leave him, even at the urging of his three older brothers in Goulburn who had begged him to evacuate.

He told them that he and Mr Purcell had a plan to get out. Mr Purcell found his friend unconscious in his ute when he failed to return from a run to get water on the farm.

Mr Harrison's brother Peter said he had no prior heart conditions. "I just think he was overcome by heat, smoke, exhaustion, running around trying to put out spot fires everywhere," he said.

"He's a hero in our eyes. A great Aussie hero."

John Smith, 71 Nerrigundah, NSW JOHN Smith (below), who retired from Moruya TAFE, is believed to have died on December 30, fighting to save his property in the tiny community of Nerrigundah, inland from Bodalla.

He decided to clear bush around his property and was reported missing when he lost contact with his wife Josie and their daughter Emerald, 10. His older son David Platte is an army veteran.

Mr Smith's body was found on January 6, after a large-scale land search. Police found him dead between the property and a car, which had both been destroyed.

Emerald Smith had earlier used Coles gift cards she had been given for her birthday to buy treats for members of the Rural Fire Service Long Beach brigade on the south coast.

On every bag, she wrote beautiful messages like: "Thank you for spending YOUR time for OUR lives".

David Moresi, 69 Johnsonville, VIC FOREST fire management contractor David Moresi died in a vehicle rollover in East Gippsland on November 30.

His car rolled when he drove through the fire ground after a day of supervising bulldozers digging fire breaks.

Daughter Kelly Douglass said: "He was a really good and caring dad, he loved his grandkids and would do anything for them." Mr Moresi (below) and his wife Judi had been together since they were 15. The former schoolteacher had been due to fly to the Philippines on Boxing Day to help build a school.

Bill Slade, 60 Wonthaggi, VIC A FUNERAL will be held today for "Bushfire Bill", who was killed by a falling tree at Anglers Rest on January 11.

The veteran firefighter and father of two died while working with a taskforce to consolidate the fire edge.

Mr Slade (below) had received a commendation in November for 40 years' -service with the forestry agency.

Mr Slade's wife Carol said that she "never thought that this would be something that would be happening to us". "You gave us so much, and have been my rock for nearly 40 years," she said of her husband.

Mick Roberts, 67 Buchan, VIC GREAT-GRANDFATHER Mick Roberts (below) was found dead in his fire-ravaged home in Buchan on New Year's Day.

Remembered as a larrikin and town legend, he chose to stay at his Sunny Point Rd home as the fire approached.

The cattle farmer had been painting his home with two mates, who fled for safety in a nearby river.

Niece Leah Parsons said her uncle was a tough man who did not believe in running, even for his own life.

Fred Becker Maramingo Creek, VIC TIMBER worker Fred Becker suffered a heart attack after defending his and neighbouring homes on New Year's Eve.

The third-generation sawmill worker, was found inside his fire--ravaged home at Maramingo Creek near Genoa. Mr Becker (above) collapsed after working around the clock to put out flames at his and neighbouring properties.

Ron Selth, 69 Charleston, SA RON Selth "tackled the furies, put up a valiant fight and went out in a blaze of glory", according to his friend Paul Edwards.

The engineer and passionate farmer (below) died while desperately trying to defend his farm from the oncoming Cudlee Creek fire in South Australia on December 20.

Richard Lang, 78, and Clayton Lang, 43 Kangaroo Island, SA KNOWN as Richie to his family, and Dick to friends, famous South Australian bush pilot Richard Lang (below left) was a larger-than-life personality with a sense of adventure.

At 78, he died, alongside his youngest son Clayton, 43, (below right) while fighting a fire near their Kangaroo Island hobby farm on January 4.

In an emotional funeral service on January 17, Mr Lang's son Justin said: "He loved doing what he did, travelling and showing people the Outback, telling people interesting stories on the way." Clayton "Clarrie" Lang, a top Adelaide plastic surgeon, was remembered as someone who "sucked the marrow out of life" at his funeral in Adelaide on January 17. His brother Lachlan said the keen skydiver and rally driver enjoyed "taking things to the extreme".

Mat Kavanagh, 43 Alexandra, VIC FIREFIGHTER Mat Kavanagh, a veteran who fought the Marysville inferno on Black Saturday in 2009, died when the ute he was a passenger in crashed into a car at Thornton, near Mansfield, Victoria, on January 3.

His brother Mike Kavanagh described the loss as "a crushing blow for all of us". "He was kind and friendly to every person he met. He was a gentleman who lived life in the sweet spot. He made you feel famous, the most important person in the room." Mat Kavanagh, a forest management firefighter, had helped put out seven unattended campfires before the collision on the Goulburn Valley Highway.

Colleague Steve Smith said: "He was a one-in-a-million kind of bloke." He is survived by wife Jude, children Reuben and Kate and parents Marise and Mick. A 46-year-old man has been charged over the fatal crash.

Chris Savva, 64 South Arm, NSW CHRIS Savva's family has paid tribute to the grandfather who successfully defended his NSW north coast home from fire, only to find the wooden bridge - his only way out - destroyed by the flames.

The long-term resident of South Arm, near Bowraville, was found dead on November 9 in his upturned SUV after it ran down an embankment when he had turned around to try and make it back home. He lived 18km outside town.

Of Greek-Cypriot heritage, Mr Savva had three children, three stepchildren and nine grandchildren. "He was a doting father and his grandchildren were the apple of his eye. He was a wonderful man, one of his daughters Bianca Waters, 36, said.

"He was incredibly kind and had a great sense of humour. He really was a hero."

Bob Lindsay, 77, and Gwen Hyde, 68 Coongbar, NSW NEWLYWEDS Bob Lindsay and Gwen Hyde (above) perished side-byside on October 9 trying to save their isolated property at Coongbar, which backs on to the Keybarbin State Forest in northern NSW.

The retired service station owner and the well-known local farmer married at the Casino courthouse just three years earlier after falling in love late in life. Ms Hyde's former husband, Archie, had lost his battle with dementia. Mr Lindsay was a local hero after he famously used a broom handle to scare off a machete-wielding robber at Casino's Liberty Service Station, which he used to own.

Friends said the couple, who had children from their earlier marriages, would not have stood a chance when the Long Gully Road fire roared through as easterly winds picked up.

The fire had been burning since a lightning strike on September 5

THE UNIDENTIFIED

Male, 59.

Yarrowitch, NSW A 59-YEAR-OLD man died six weeks after he was winched from his rural property, about 70km southeast of Walcha in NSW, suffering severe burns.

He was found on November 7 by a Parks and Wildlife Services officer after he was burnt taking shelter from the Stockyard Flat fire in a water tank.

Man, 56 Coolagolite, NSW PARAMEDICS discovered a 56-year-old man's body outside a home at the NSW town of Coolagolite, near Cobargo, where the massive Currowan blaze fires reduced properties to ash in just minutes on December 31. Neighbours said he was a loner who kept to himself.

Man, 75 Yatte Yattah, NSW The body of a 75-year-old man was found early on January 31 in a burnt-out car on a road off the Princes Highway at Yatte Yattah, near the fire-ravaged community of Lake Conjola where 89 homes were lost.

Man, 62 Sussex Inlet, NSW THE body of a 62-year-old man was found in his car at Sussex Inlet on the NSW south coast where the road was burnt out and locals and holidaymakers had evacuated to the beach.

Man, 84 Cobargo, NSW A COBARGO man was remembered as a genuine "country boy" following his death after he suffered critical burns at his home in the bushfires that ripped through the town on New Year's Eve.It is believed he was trying to defend his property when he and his dog Bella were overrun by fire. He was treated for severe burns at hospital and later discharged. Then, just after 2am on Saturday, January 18, he sought medical assistance after feeling unwell and later went into cardiac arrest. Police said that despite the efforts of hospital staff, the 84-year-old could not be revived.

We asked the CFA and the company2020-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:04ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 8What's being done to stop the big powerline project causing bushfires? We asked the CFA and the companyAlex Ford

With the bushfire danger period fast approaching, residents in the area of interest for the Western Victoria Transmission Network Project are demanding answers for how the high-voltage powerlines will affect bushfire risk.

One resident, Karolina Kuzmich, from Wattle Flat, said she was afraid of being isolated in a bushfire if the powerline crossed her property.

"We're in a high-risk fire zone, our property backs onto the Creswick State Forest, with a boundary at Slaty Creek," she said.

READ MORE: Uncertainty causing stress, frustration in communities

"We have one road that's access in and out, in front of our property - it's a narrow road, gravel, trees across it.

"If the transmission lines come across our property, there's two places it will go - one is behind the property between the house and the forest, (and) we wouldn't have the opportunity to run down and check (on our animals).

"The other option for the transmission line is between our house and the access road - and that means if there's a fire, then we could be locked into our property."

Transmission lines are different to distribution lines, and have different rules around easements - project proponent AusNet noted the Black Saturday Royal Commission found that in 96 years, no bushfire had been caused by a transmission line.

The Courier asked the CFA and AusNet several questions regarding bushfire risk and received detailed answers.

In a statement, CFA west region deputy chief fire officer Michael Boatman said standard operating procedures include processes for safely working around high-voltage transmission lines and large pylons in association with response to a variety of hazards, including bushfires.

"Strategies, tactics and specific capabilities used to fight fires vary depending on the forecast weather conditions, fire behaviour and location," he said.

"CFA will undertake direct attack on fires adjacent to high voltage transmission lines easements provided fuel, topography and fire behaviour conditions allow this to be done safely.

"Where high voltage lines have been deenergised, firefighting will occur on the easement if this is part of the strategy and tactics being employed.

"Firefighting aircraft can and do operate around high-voltage transmission lines where that is part of the strategy. The pilot is responsible for maintaining separation just like they would with any other vertical hazard.

"As staying and defending a property during a bushfire is very dangerous, CFA recommends residents that leaving early is the best option when living in a high-risk bushfire area. If residents leave early it will also be safe for them to pass under transmission lines."

A spokesperson for AusNet said assessing bushfire risk is part of the Environmental Effects Statement investigation, and the company had a working relationship with fire authorities.

"We are undertaking a rigorous and transparent assessment of bushfire risk and ensuring that any risk is minimised and managed is a key priority for the project," they said.

"The bushfire risk mitigation strategies we propose to use include the following:

The transmission line easements will be managed to protect the towers and lines from fire.

Easements are wide enough that if a tall tree outside the easement were to fall it would not reach the towers or the lines.

A rigorous vegetation management program will be implemented to eliminate vegetation fuel loads in easements.

A state-of-the-art protection system will detect faults and shut off the power in milliseconds.

Fires are actively monitored from our control room. We work closely with Emergency Management Victoria (ESV) in the case of an emergency.

Easements can offer important protections by acting as firebreaks.

You can also head to the project website to access the fact sheet on bushfires.

"Community input is a key part of the process and the company is dedicated to working with stakeholders, all key risks and benefits are adequately assessed and appropriate mitigation measures implemented.

"Our findings and resulting plans will be reviewed by the relevant government agencies as part of the EES process."

The exact route for the powerlines has not yet been determined, and is expected to be announced in November.

IN THE NEWS

"If they haven't decided the path, how could they possibly address everyone's issues?" she said.

"In some ways, I can understand AusNet, if they had come to us and said 'this is the pathway we're going on,' they would have had community uproar because there was no consultation there either - in fairness to them, their hands are tied."

READ THE FULL RESPONSE FROM THE CFA BELOW CFA West Region Deputy Chief Officer Michael Boatman:

Responding to and suppressing bushfires is a complicated and hazardous task, regardless of the setting and any adjacent infrastructure..

CFA's standard operating procedures include processes for safely working around high-voltage transmission lines and large pylons in association with response to a variety of hazards including bushfires.

Strategies, tactics and specific capabilities used to fight fires vary depending on the forecast weather conditions, fire behaviour and location.

CFA will undertake direct attack on fires adjacent to high voltage transmission lines easements provided fuel, topography and fire behaviour conditions allow this to be done safely. Where high voltage lines have been deenergised, firefighting will occur on the easement if this is part of the strategy and tactics being employed.

Firefighting aircraft can and do operate around high-voltage transmission lines where that is part of the strategy. The pilot is responsible for maintaining separation just like they would with any other vertical hazard ie communications tower, masts, wind turbine etc. The fire at Bunyip state park in March 2019 is an example of when firebombing helicopters worked in close proximity to the transmission lines containing fire prior to ground crew arrival.

Powerline easements may reduce overall bushfire risk on some properties due to the modification and maintenance of fuel conditions, depending on the conditions on the day of a fire.

As staying and defending a property during a bushfire is very dangerous, CFA recommends residents that leaving early is the best option when living in a high-risk bushfire area. If residents leave early it will also be safe for them to pass under transmission lines.

Leaving when a bushfire is already threatening the property or adjacent infrastructure is extremely dangerous regardless of whether the infrastructure includes transmission lines or pylons. Travelling in smoky conditions when visibility of other traffic including responding emergency services is low is not safe.

READ THE FULL RESPONSE FROM AUSNET BELOW:

- what measures are in the initial plans for the project to mitigate bushfire risk?

We are undertaking a rigorous and transparent assessment of bushfire risk and ensuring that any risk is minimised and managed is a key priority for the project.

As part of this, we are currently preparing an Environment Effect Statement (EES) which will consider the environmental impacts of the project, including bushfire risk.

As part of this process we must complete a large number of technical investigations and reports for submission to government.

Community input is a key part of the process and the company is dedicated to working with stakeholders, all key risks and benefits are adequately assessed and appropriate mitigation measures implemented.

Our findings and resulting plans will be reviewed by the relevant government agencies as part of the EES process.

The bushfire risk mitigation strategies we propose to use include the following:

The transmission line easements will be managed to protect the towers and lines from fire. Easements are wide enough that if a tall tree outside the easement were to fall it would not reach the towers or the lines. A rigorous vegetation management program will be implemented to eliminate vegetation fuel loads in easements. A state-of-the-art protection system will detect faults and shut off the power in milliseconds. Fires are actively monitored from our control room. We work closely with Emergency Management Victoria (ESV) in the case of an emergency. Easements can offer important protections by acting as firebreaks. You can also head to the project website to access the fact sheet on bushfires. - how are transmission lines different to distribution lines when it comes to fire risk?

The project is proposing to build transmission lines between Sydenham and Bulgana. The following factors differentiate transmission lines from distribution lines with regard to fire risk.

Transmission lines are bound by regulations to maintain a controlled easement that doesn't permit vegetation to build up fuel load and requires line of fall trees to be cleared or cut back so no tree can contact the line if it failed at the root base. That means transmission lines require larger easements and clearance than distribution lines.

When it comes to conductor clearance above ground, transmission lines are two to three times higher than distribution, which significantly eliminates the risk of contact from vehicles.

The spacing of conductors on Victorian transmission lines are far apart enough to prevent even the largest bird, including eagles, or animals to bridge between the phases or phase to earth structure. This is not the case with distribution lines.

Transmission lines also run aerial earth wires above the conductors which protect from lightning strike, which distribution lines do not have.

Transmission protection, which interrupts the power in cases of a fault, operates within milliseconds and is an order of magnitude more efficient than the distribution protection system.

- in an emergency, how close can people get to towers?

Transmission easements have been used to slow or stop fire fronts.

We work closely with State and Local Government, Emergency Management Victoria (EMV) and the Country Fire Association (CFA) in an emergency.

The easements can allow more concentrated fire-fighting efforts due to the lower fuel load, thereby assisting with containment.

This was clearly demonstrated in the 2019 Bunyip State Forest fire.

- could residents flee a bushfire by escaping underneath powerlines?

Communities should always adhere to official emergency services advice in the case of a fire.

- is there risk of shocks or 'flashovers' in a bushfire situation?

The transmission lines are designed to automatically disconnect by control systems at both ends of the line to protect the line and surroundings from damage.

Vegetation control in and around an easement ensures there is not enough fuel to enable a flame to reach a conductor.

Smoke density if large enough can trip a circuit.

For this to occur a severe wildfire must have reached the edge of the easement.

- would more land be required in forested/bushland areas to create a firebreak?

No, the easement distances are the same and Line of fall trees in all cases are managed so they cannot contact the line.

Assessments of vegetation and fuel load will be undertaken during the EES studies.

This is one of the reasons we will be requesting access to properties that are within the area of interest to assess on the ground conditions in detail, to feed into the final project design.

- how will aerial firefighting units work around the towers?

As is already the case in other areas, we will continue to work with EMV and the CFA to ensure aerial firefighting can operate safely in the vicinity of the high-voltage transmission lines.

The transmission towers are well defined on aeronautical maps.

Recent incidents in the Latrobe Valley saw firebombing helicopters work near transmission lines to contain a fire before the CFA ground crew arrived.

- my understanding is the collapse of the Cressy towers in February was because of a once in a century weather event acting on older infrastructure - how will this risk be mitigated for the new pylons? How often are they inspected on the ground?

The towers in Cressy that were brought to the ground earlier in the year were the victim of very rare, extreme and destructive weather conditions, involving a convective downdraft.

In addition, in comparison to the planned WVTNP towers, the towers that were brought down in Cressy were designed and built over 35 years ago.

The towers for this project are being designed to comply to the current Australian Standard which include significant updates over historical standards.

The design of these towers will also involve the use of sophisticated, contemporary computer modelling which enables the analysis of complex load cases.

urn:contentItem:5Y8N-2451-JD34-V4HV-00000-00Authorities urge community not to be complacent about fire risk2020-02-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:04ZLexisNexisAuthorities urge community not to be complacent about fire riskHayley Elg

Emergency services are urging communities not to become complacent despite the state experiencing a brief reprieve from the hot and dry summer, with this time of year one that has historically seen some of the state's worst fires.

Earlier this week, the Country Fire Authority warned that despite the rain and cooler weather in recent days, the risk of fast-running grass and scrub fires still existed, with February a month in which many of the state's worst fires have occurred.

Related coverage: Fire season not over yet, warns Country Fire Authority

Just over a year on from the Hepburn fire at Mannings Road, at which flames licked relatively close to the township, emergency services are calling on the Daylesford and Hepburn communities to remain vigilant and to ensure personal fire plans are in place.

Earlier in the fire season, facing another hot and windy day, emergency services including the CFA, Victoria Police and Forest Fire Management Victoria gathered for a preparedness meeting, looking at what the plan would be in the instance of a fire, especially in the first hour before back-up resources arrive.

Understanding that community concern and confusion about how an emergency situation would be managed in the shire existed, with residents asking how they could prepare for the potential of a disastrous event to unfold on their doorsteps, such as what has occurred in the east of the state and across Australia in recent months, emergency services decided to create an informative video.

Related coverage: Buninyong-Mt Helen Fire Brigade urges community members to create detailed fire plans

With the area deemed to be a high fire risk due to the townships being nestled amongst bushland, a perceived need to come out of the meeting was to further encourage the community to engage with authorities to help to protect themselves and to remain aware of the surrounding environment.

Most of all, they want people living in all parts of the region, even if in the centre of a township, to have a fire plan.

Do not be complacent While back-up from surrounding fire brigades would be quick to turn out if a fire was to break out near the towns, it is possible a fire could impact quite quickly before other resources such as air support arrive. And if it was a particularly bad day with many fires burning across the state, resources could well stretched.

Related coverage: Encouraging female leadership in the CFA

Related coverage: They came within metres of disaster but still consider themselves lucky

CFA District 15 Commander Luke Kneebone said that during the Hepburn fire in 2019, conditions had worked in authorities' favour: there were no other major fires burning and so authorities received all resources they asked for, including air support, and a wind change late in the day had pushed the fire away from the township.

Despite this good result - with there not being any injuries or property losses as a result of the blaze - he said authorities did not want this to create a sense of complacency within the community.

"We want people to understand that may not always be the case. There are lots of factors that can influence our response, including weather. If the weather is really bad, we may not be able to get aircraft up in the air and if there are other incidents, we may not be able to get as many resources as quickly," he said.

Watch the video here:

Commander Kneebone said authorities wanted the community to remain vigilant so that their fire plans could be put in place, if need be.

"We want people who live in the Daylesford and Hepburn area to stay alert," he said. "So knowing the fire danger rating on a particular day, keeping an eye on the weather conditions and VicEmergency app and then applying all that information to your plan."

Facing engagement challenges With its reputation as 'Spa Country' meaning there are always large groups of tourists wandering around the town and its various attractions, authorities are also trying to engage tourism and accommodation providers, to try to spread the message to visitors.

This includes leaving a fire-affected area if safe to do so, as dangerous curiosity was a problem for authorities at the 2019 fire, when a number of people travelled along small tracks to access back areas that had already been evacuated in order to watch the fire and aircraft from a higher vantage point.

Related coverage: How authorities work behind the scenes on a high fire danger day

Related coverage: Stickybeaks cause frustration for firefighters

Sergeant Matt Flood from Daylesford Police Station is the shire's Municipal Emergency Response Coordinator.

A Municipal Emergency Management Plan is required for every local government area and encourages familiarisation and planning across agencies for a number of different incidents that may occur in a particular area - from flooding to fire, road trauma, missing people and even though not an incident, major events.

Sergeant Flood said emergency services were working with the community in regards to fire preparedness but faced some challenges such as a lack of phone reception in certain areas and informing visitors to the area of the messaging.

If an incident such as fire were to occur on a weekend, when traffic in the towns always increases, it would be a lot more problematic for authorities.

Importance of fire plans The policing role at a fire is to keep the area safe for the control agency - either the CFA and FFMV - and to manage an evacuation process if need be, to door knock houses and to set up traffic management points and road blocks to ensure emergency vehicles can access the impacted area.

Both Commander Kneebone and Sergeant Flood urged the community to ensure they have fire plans in place, and if it includes leaving early, to know the trigger point for leaving and not to wait for authorities to knock at the door.

Planning where to travel to, such as to a family or friend's house or to a bigger regional centre such as Ballarat until the fire risk has reduced should also be part of the plan.

With both residents and tourists trying to escape the area if a fire were approaching, too many people on the roads in a panic would cause congestion around the townships, with people trying to flee as emergency services try to gain access to fight the fire.

While Sergeant Flood acknowledged that there would always be people in a situation in which they would need to access relief centres, if most people have planned and monitored a situation, they should be out of the area.

Relief centres - or places of last resort - are determined based on the situation and where the threat is, meaning emergency services are fluid and flexible in determining a location.

The towns are too small to cater to thousands of people crowded in the streets or at a relief centre - or places of last resort - so both residents and tourists are encouraged to leave an area before the risk is heightened.

Commander Kneebone said people needed to be aware of the risk, including that with dry conditions, it is possible fires could engulf a town.

"Plans need to be individualised and that's why we want people to engage with this, so that they understand the environment they live, work in or are travelling to and think about what the plan is for a number of different possible scenarios," he said.

"You need to be engaged, have a plan, a back up plan and to practice that plan."

Another part of fire, though insidious but which carries a big risk, is heat health. Sergeant Flood said the community could always improve in the ways in which it looks after each other.

"More people died as a result of the extremely high temperatures leading up to and during the Black Saturday event," he said. "It is something, particularly with an older community, that people need to be mindful of looking after older neighbours, friends and family.

"With climate change, it is something that will become more prevalent - it will be hot for days at a time."

Stay up to date with Daylesford police on the Moorabool Eyewatch page. More information about bushfire planning, preparation and leaving early can be read at cfa.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:61XC-N031-JD34-V0YG-00000-00Bushfires are hellishly stranger. What can we do?2021-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:03ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 28Bushfires are hellishly stranger. What can we do?ExplainerSherryn Groch

Ancient wisdom is coming to the fore as fires turn into lethal tornados, writes Sherryn Groch.

It was on New Year's Eve 2019, with the horror summer not yet done and a global pandemic still to come, that Greg Mullins saw something once thought to be firefighting legend: a blaze so big it generated its own lightning storm.

As a kid, watching his father rush off to fight fires and then signing up himself to his local brigade at 13, he'd heard the stories of such phenomena. "But none of us expected to see one."

On the last night of 2019, when the storm front came, it blocked out the sun, throwing down spears of lightning that ignited new fires as the inferno spread in every direction and tore through homes on the South Coast.

"You could hear the thunder," says Mullins, a former fire commissioner of NSW. "The fire was racing across people's front lawns. Even the kangaroos couldn't escape. I just felt totally powerless."

It was the start of the biggest outbreak of firestorms ever recorded. The smoke plumes from the Black Summer reached into space, as high as a nuclear blast. On the ground, a fire tornado or a large "fire whirl" flipped an eight-tonne tanker and killed a firefighter.

Bushfires aren't just getting bigger and more frequent in Australia. They're getting stranger. Moving faster, flaring unpredictably, changing the weather. While once "good fire" helped rejuvenate the landscape under the careful watch of its First Nations, today global warming is fanning flames too big to live with.

During Australia's deadliest bushfire disaster, Black Saturday, nightmarish weather conditions came together in Victoria one February day in 2009. The fires moved fast, trapping people in cars and homes, and burning with the power of 1500 atomic bombs. By the time the 2019-20 Black Summer arrived, drought had turned much of the country into a tinderbox, and the flames didn't seem to end. A recent royal commission warned "what was unprecedented is now our future".

We are not alone. Fire seasons around the world are stretching out, overlapping, intensifying. Places that have never burnt before, such as the Arctic circle and parts of the Amazon, are going up.

Even during a wetter La Nina season this year for Australia, Perth and Fraser Island have burnt.

How are fire seasons changing?

Rachael Cavanagh knows what good fire is. Her people - the Minyungbal and Yugambeh nations - have been wielding it and watching it change and rejuvenate the landscape for millennia.

But, as a career firefighter in northern NSW, Cavanagh was also on the front line of the Black Summer. In Coffs Harbour, crews were exhausted from a long winter of fires by the time cities were being engulfed by smoke. "We knew it would be bad but it just didn't stop," she says.

"Forest would burn and two weeks later we'd be in there again fighting another fire. It was strange, surreal."

More than 9.7 million hectares, an area bigger than England, burnt across Australia. Thirty-three people were killed and hundreds died from complications linked to smoke inhalation.

For wildlife, it was the single biggest catastrophe in recorded history - 3 billion creatures killed or displaced, and their ecosystems decimated.

At the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre, which is now working to update Australia's existing McArthur forest fire danger index, chief executive Richard Thornton says the sheer size and duration of the fires left few places for animals to seek refuge.

Despite fake news about an "arson emergency", almost all of the fires were started by lightning.

As the climate warms, more violent storms and drier and hotter conditions are coming together to make bigger bushfires. Australia's driest and hottest year on record was 2019. The Bureau of Meteorology even had to introduce a new colour code to capture some of the extreme temperatures. When the season began, some towns had already run out of water to drink, let alone fight fires. And the deadly Black Saturday still holds the record for Melbourne's hottest day at 46.4 degrees.

Tom Beer was the world's first scientist to link climate change to increased bushfires, in 1988 - he was considering scenarios far into the future, when the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere might be double what it was then. While emissions have ramped up faster than predicted, Australia is only halfway (1.4 degrees) into the 3 degrees of warming Beer was modelling. But the fires are burning as if we are already there.

"In fact, they're even worse," Beer says. "Back then, we thought every year's danger would be as bad as Ash Wednesday [in 1983]. We couldn't really imagine anything worse. Now they're bigger, they're more dangerous, and the time between these horrors is shrinking down, from decades to years."

Twenty years later, in 2008, Ross Garnaut built on the work of Beer and the CSIRO when he made the haunting prediction that hellish fire seasons would be "directly observable by 2020".

Mullins says the seasons are getting more expensive and more exhausting, running so long the window is narrowing for agencies to safely burn off vegetation. "You don't even need a [warm] El Nino event to get a bad season now."

How is fire behaviour changing?

Leading fire historian Stephen Pyne likens fire to a driverless car. "At some point, there'll be a sharp curve called climate change or a tricky intersection where town and country come together, or a lot of hazards left over from land clearing," he says.

Most homes are lost in ember attacks, sparks spitting ahead of a bushfire that come in like a locust storm, he says. Such spot fires were once common a few hundred metres ahead of a fire. Mullins says: "Now we're recording them 12 kilometres ahead.

"During Black Saturday too, people saw a smoke column about 20, 30 kilometres away. The next minute their house was on fire."

For all the recent focus on fuel loads in Australia, fire scientist Jason Sharples says it makes little difference in extreme conditions. "That's when usual fire behaviour goes out the window and it's being driven by mass spotting. Hazard reduction isn't going to stop that," he says.

During the Black Summer, one of the biggest shocks came at night when the fires seemed to burn just as ferociously as they did during the heat of the day.

Mullins recalls battling 30 metre-tall flames at 1am. "A strong wind kept roaring through the bush ... Nothing human beings can do to stop a fire like that."

Are firestorms increasing?

Twenty years ago, when meteorologist Mike Fromm was called in to investigate mysterious clouds showing up on satellite feeds over the US, he saw in the data what firefighters had long called "the monster". These clouds were coming from forest fires.

"It kind of broke the rules of what a thunderstorm should be able to do," Fromm says now of his discovery, that "fire-breathing dragon" known as the pyrocumulus firestorm. "[They] act in many ways like a volcano, injecting stuff that comes off the fire into the stratosphere."

Before the Black Summer, there had been only about 60 firestorms confirmed or suspected in Australia. Then, in just one season, that number nearly doubled. Some even started, unusually, after sunset, Fromm says.

The winds inside firestorms can reach cyclone speeds. "These [storms] can exhibit the worst behaviours," Fromm says. "Thunder, hail, lightning ... tornados. They're the least predictable, the most dangerous [for] firefighters. But it's odd. Typically, the bigger the thunderstorm the heavier the rain. With pyrostorms, it's the opposite. They have a bigger boost to their updrafts but produce almost no rain. Just a lot of smoke."

So, how big does a fire need to be to create its own weather? Fromm says there's no clear-cut size or temperature but it needs to cover "a very large piece of real estate" and burn "as hot as a fire can be so it generates that thermal bubble that starts the storm".

It's likely scientists are detecting more firestorms now because they know what to look for, but fires are also burning bigger because of climate change.

Filming in the eye of a pyrostorm, that swirling vortex of smoke and ice crystals and forest debris, is still the "holy grail" for Fromm and other firestorm chasers. "We don't quite do a Twister thing where we get a hunch and throw something into the storm," Fromm says. But he has been on planes flown by NASA and his own agency, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, through suspected pyrostorm plumes. "You could smell the smoke flooding the cockpit at 34,000 feet. It's like a big chimney."

After the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima at the end of World War II, scientists think the mushroom cloud that formed was caused by firestorms from the infernos it ignited, rather than the initial bomb blast itself.

How do we live with fires of the future?

The Black Summer didn't have to happen, at least not the way it did, says Cavanagh. "When our old people used to walk country and swim and do all the care they do, they put fire in as they went, the right fire at the right time to clear out grasses ... or help [echidnas] forage ... [We've] been fighting since colonisation to manage country again. So when fire comes in, it's not the big one that rages because nothing's burnt in 30 years."

Unlike the walls of flame put in during a hazard reduction burn, Indigenous burns are lit in spiral, mosaic patterns, with room for animals to escape. They don't roar into the treetops, they are not set when birds are nesting or bees are pollinating, when the winds are too strong. "You can walk in behind that fire and you should be able to brush the ash off the top of the soil and it will still be cool," Cavanagh says. "Only the outer bark of the trees will burn."

Unlocking the ecological puzzle of how Aboriginal people managed such a flammable landscape for so long could be key to Australia's future in a more fire-prone world. While more training and investment is needed, Cavanagh stresses the knowledge is not lost. "Often our women hold the fire lore and the medicine and they teach it to the children. My eight-year-old can read Country. She knows when to burn."

Up north, where Aboriginal communities have more land rights, cultural burns have been integrated into the forestry service for some time. Down south, it's more fragmented. Crucial windows to burn often get missed under the slow grind of bureaucracy, Cavanagh says. Some agencies won't pay local nations for their work and, while the Black Summer has sparked serious talk of scaling up the practice, Indigenous leaders stress burns must be led by local Aboriginal people, not merely tacked on to existing regimes.

After the "Big Blowup" inferno of 1910 that burnt across the west of the US, some experts there advocated for reintroducing the traditional, cool burns of Native American tribes. Instead, agencies pivoted to a hardline "suppression" approach, the way fires are put out in cities.

Jason Sharples, a Bundajlung man, says traditional burning might itself need to adapt to a warming climate and evolved terrain. But, if done right, he says it could be Australia's best chance against worsening fire seasons. "These fires can be put out years before they actually start. Of course, it's not all we have to do."

Bushfire season is often followed by inquiry season, by soul-searching and reflection but usually, experts say, little practical action. The exception, Pyne says, was Black Saturday, which seemed to hit the Australian psyche "almost like a terrorist attack" and prompted an overhaul of community warnings. "Now [the Black] Summer is the same."

Prime Minister Scott Morrison spoke of adapting to worsening conditions, but the 2020 royal commission directly named the elephant in the room that needed policy attention: climate change.

Mullins heads a group of retired, senior-ranking firefighters calling on Australia to lead a rapid shift to a zero emissions economy. "We can say what the current [emergency services agency] commissioners can't," he says.

"COVID has shown the government knows how to listen to scientists. Well, this is an emergency, too, and we can stop it getting worse." More bushfires also mean more carbon released into the atmosphere, a wicked feedback loop. If the Black Summer fires were their own country, they would have been one of the world's top emitters.

Despite the US experience, Pyne says some remote fires may still need to be put out fast - that's where drones and other technologies can help spot them early. The Morrison government says it will work to improve information sharing, including from satellites, but has largely ignored calls from firefighters - and now the royal commission - for more investment in large water-bombing aircraft.

"Under extreme conditions, if we leave fires burning far out and they get legs, an ember storm can blow them in anyway," Sharples says.

David Bowman, an ecologist pioneering the new field of pyrogeography at the University of Tasmania, says communities must be better prepared for when fires do come close. "It should be like living with cyclones and earthquakes. We've got too much [urban sprawl] pushing into forest. We've got the wrong houses in the wrong places," he says.

Ninety-nine per cent of the homes lost in the Black Summer were within 500 metres of fire-prone land, according to the Insurance Council of Australia.

Experts agree we need to get smarter about clearing close to properties. But Mullins warns against kneejerk reactions - NSW's new plan to allow landowners to clear bush within 25 metres of their fence line without environmental approvals was not recommended by a recent state inquiry and has raised concerns for koala populations.

Deforestation has largely got the world into this mess, Mullins says. "We've changed rainfall patterns by chopping down rainforest and with so many species in trouble [after the fires], we have to be more careful than ever."

Building to fire codes is also expensive, often a big ask for communities already hit hard by fires. According to Sharples, even Australia's fire standard is designed to deal with the usual predictable blaze and not the fire of extremes. "There's a little about embers but it's mostly measured by radiant heat near the house."

Bowman likens the change needed in Australia to the incremental road safety reforms under which everything from seatbelts to mandatory insurance became standard. "We need everyone on board, private industry as well as government - only this has to be taken at a sprint. We've pressed the climate-change stopwatch now."

The heroes in the story may well be local councils, he says, rallying and educating their communities. Or the change may be driven by the insurance industry: soaring premiums have begun to price people out of wildfire-prone areas in the US. "No one has [solved] this problem yet. We can't look to a Sweden. But we are so much on the front line. Australia could be driving this."

In the chaos of 2020, Pyne began thinking more and more of fire as a virus - not living itself but feeding on what is. "Protecting our homes, clearing out defensible space then becomes like social distancing. Building fire-resistant homes is like wearing a mask; lighting good fires to stave off bad ones is building up herd immunity in the landscape. But there's no vaccine for bushfires," he says.

At best, Bowman says: "It's a negotiated truce."

urn:contentItem:60T3-7D21-F0NT-H036-00000-00'One of Australia's first climate casualties died 11km from federal parliament'2020-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:04ZLexisNexis'One of Australia's first climate casualties died 11km from federal parliament'CrikeyABSTRACT

The 2003 Canberra fires resulted in the loss of 470 homes and four lives.

FULL TEXT

In his new book, Paddy Manning charts the human cost of climate change over the past decade. Body Count is a journey into loss, sacrifice and heroism. In this extract, he tells the story of David Tener, whose wife Alison died in the 2003 Canberra fires. David Tener lost his wife Alison in the Canberra bushfires of 2003. The couple were renting a Defence home in Duffy, a dormitory suburb in the city's south-west. He worked in maintenance for the Air Force, and she had been a stay-at-home mum to their three boys until she started a new job at Air Services. They'd met when they were young, on a Contiki tour of America in the mid-'80s. Both were travelling with mates, and he'd gone up to her -- a total stranger -- and sat in her lap when they were on the bus. Alison thought David was a bit forward, but they hit it off and got married in 1987. When he proposed, David told her in all seriousness: "You've got to understand, I married the Air Force first". Both knew there would be sacrifices. They moved around the country as he was rotated through bases at Fairbairn, Williamstown and then Richmond, north-west of Sydney. By late 2002 David was facing a possible deployment to Iraq, returning to the base after Christmas, and he suggested to Alison on a whim that maybe she would like a couple of weeks to herself, offering to take the boys to stay with her parents in Coffs Harbour. Alison agreed, having never had a break as a full-time mum. So she was home alone on Saturday, January 18 as an unprecedented firestorm threatened Canberra.  The Teners' home in Duffy was a two-storey weatherboard on Burrendong Street, just one block back from enormous, thick pine plantations at the south-western edge of the ACT. David distinctly remembers being in the upstairs rumpus room one day with Alison. "She was looking out the window at all the birds singing and the trees and whatever, and she said, 'Oh, it's just so beautiful here, I love it. It's so wonderful'. You know, I still remember saying to her, 'Yeah', I said, 'but if a fire ever gets into that forest they'll never stop it, it'll be like a nuke going off'." The 2003 bushfires had started on January 8, when dry lightning strikes set off more than 100 wildfires in the Australian Alps that would take out almost 2 million hectares of high country across the ACT, NSW and Victoria. "What stood out about 2003 is that it was all lightning," says Phil Zylstra, a researcher with the Bushfires and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre at the University of Wollongong, "and there's no indication that that has happened since colonisation of Australia. They were an order of magnitude larger than the worst we'd had for half a century before then." Four large fires threatened Canberra: one at McIntyres Hut in the Brindabella National Park in NSW, and three in the ACT's Namadgi National Park -- at Mount Gingera, Bendora and Stockyard Spur. Firefighters initially believed all four could be brought under control, but the predicted fire weather was worse than Ash Wednesday and the Territory was tinder-dry as the Millennium Drought set in: river flows had dropped, grass cured, fuel loads were heavy, and all dead-and-down timber was flammable. Gradually the main fires converged, and after a feared north-westerly wind shift on the Saturday morning a "fire tornado" whipped up between the Bendora and McIntyres Hut fires -- the first time such a phenomenon had been observed anywhere in the world. Firefighters were stunned: the fire front moved at 20km an hour, later described as the fastest documented rate of spread of a forest fire anywhere. It had become unstoppable, and the ACT's fire chiefs knew that day the firestorm would burn through the pine plantations and into Canberra.  Canberra, January 19, 2003. The suburbs of Chapman and Duffy following a bush fire that raged through the ACT western suburbs (Image: AAP /Alan Porritt/courtesy ABC) None of this was communicated to Canberra residents, who from 2pm were growing increasingly alarmed at the approaching thick, black smoke and falling ash and embers. At last a state of emergency was declared at around 2.45 pm, which was broadcast to the public by ABC Radio via an official warning some minutes later. Even then, the broadcast suggested there were no fires in the suburbs and no evacuations, and Chief Minister Jon Stanhope, who came on air directly afterwards, said the declaration was administrative and people should not be unduly alarmed. The substance of the warning, when it finally came, was that residents should return to their homes and prepare to defend them from embers by clearing gutters, connecting hoses and wetting down the exterior, removing flammable items near the house, and so on. Residents were also told to fill their bathtubs and buckets and dampen towels -- although, as the coroner later noted, the somewhat cryptic message did not explain why. Alison admitted to a neighbour she was frightened, yet she kept calm. According to neighbours who survived, Alison seemed unsure whether to stay or go. She was seen closing the curtains, and had packed photos and a few other precious things into the car, which was in the carport ready and waiting. Her neighbours did leave, but at some point Alison must have gone back into the house -- possibly, David thinks, to get their cat -- and found herself trapped inside by a firestorm that approached like a freight train. She climbed into the bathtub, apparently misunderstanding the point of the emergency warning, which was to use the water to put out any spot fires inside the home. Alison died in the bathtub of smoke inhalation. The car in the carport survived. Up in Richmond, David had no idea that bushfires were threatening Canberra's suburbs. He was rostered off and relaxing at a mate's house-warming when he got a phone call from a friend in Canberra offering to put Alison up if she needed accommodation. David turned on the television, saw that the firestorm had swept through Duffy and then recognised his street. "I remember looking at it and going, 'Oh crap, oh crap, oh crap, that looks like my house'," David recalls. He hadn't spoken to Alison since the day before, so he called her but could not get through on her mobile or the landline. Panicky, David jumped in the car and sped down the Hume. When he got there that night, the police had his entire suburb cordoned off. He said seeing his suburb levelled was surreal. "The best way to describe it was as if a nuclear weapon had been detonated, and yet it picked and chose which houses to destroy, and which not to. Basically you had, for example, the house beside us on the left, totally intact, untouched. Our house, vaporised to the ground level. And the next house gone, and then a house standing, and then another house gone, and then two houses standing, and then, like, four houses gone. It was utterly random." In her powerful report on the four deaths that occurred that day, coroner Maria Doogan could not be certain whether Alison had heard the confusing radio warning, but singled out her case as a tragic example of the incompetence of ACT authorities and their failure to alert the public. "I don't even want to think about what was going on in her head at that moment," says David now. "Had she not gone to the house itself, she would have lived," says David, ruing that he had not been at home to get her out. "Not being there for her will forever haunt me. The guilt is unbearable." Of the 470 homes lost that day, 219 were in Duffy, with fires spreading house to house. "In hindsight," says David, "when you consider that about 500 homes were destroyed, and when you consider how ferocious and strong and powerful the fire storm was ... and when you consider that the warnings were to stay in place, or to return to your home, the fact that only four died is unbelievable." David was now put in a terrible situation. "I don't know what was worse," he recalls. "Realising that my wife had died, or having to get on the phone and tell the kids before they saw it on the TV. To this day, the most chilling thing in my heart that I can ever remember is hearing them screaming over the phone: 'Mummy, Mummy, Mummy, no, no, no'." Even after more than a decade, David says it's only in the last few years he's been able to talk about Alison's death. He commenced a class action against the ACT government for failing to manage the fires and failing to warn the public. The case ran for some years until he reached an out-of-court settlement. "They reported it as if we backed out, but we didn't," David says. "I can't disclose an amount or anything like that but I will say that it was quite pathetic. If you knew what we received, you'd be quite shocked, people have been compensated more for slipping over in the supermarket." David Tener at this wife Alison's memorial (Image: Paddy Manning) One positive for David is that in the 2019-20 fire season, the ACT Emergency Services hierarchy displayed a far more professional approach, with thorough and timely public warnings. "To this end hopefully Alison and three others did not die in vain," he says.  David describes himself as "strictly a layman" when it comes to climate science. He has no doubt the planet is warming but believes it's at least partly to do with natural cycles. "So basically I believe the planet is headed for one of its hot spells, and man is speeding it up. Like I said, I believe it's naturally occurring, but we are -- ironically, if you want to use a saying -- throwing fuel on the fire." David has no doubt that dry lightning is igniting more fires, and that it's directly related to drought and climate change. "Because you're having less moisture in the soil, you're having more loose soil getting into the air, you're getting these dust storms ... and they are going to create static and they do have to discharge somewhere, hence the dry lightning." Asked directly if he counts himself and Alison as victims of climate change, David pauses to reflect. "That's a hard one to answer, to be quite honest with you ... Australia has always had bushfires, and we always will. But I do believe we have entered a new age of bushfires, where the manner in which they are being started is new and different. And yes, that could well be put down to climate change." Later in our conversation, David circles back to answer the question again later: "If it can be shown, categorically, that the Canberra fires were started by dry lightning, then yes, I guess we could say we were a victim." Alison Tener was perhaps one of the first climate casualties in Australia. Postscript: At a May hearing of the Bushfires Royal Commission, the Bureau of Meteorology's Dr Karl Braganza said the first two decades of the century stood out as warmer than any previous period, increasing the odds of extreme weather, including more severe bushfires. "Really since the Canberra 2003 fires every jurisdiction in Australia has seen this," he said. "[We] have seen some really significant fire events that have challenged what we do to respond to them, and have really challenged what we thought fire weather looked like preceding this period."This is an extract from Body Count by Paddy Manning, published by Simon & Schuster Australia.
